issues.text: This appeal raises the important question of the constitutional validity of the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, J. This appeal raises the important question of the constitutional validity of the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and though

issues.text: On the question whether Section 4 of the Act operates as a delegation of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether Section 4 of the Act operates as a delegation of legislative power, I entirely agree with the reasoning and conclusion of my learned brother Das, who has

issues.text: whether the Bombay City Civil has jurisdiction to try a suit based on a promissory note

anchor.surface_text: whether the Bombay City Civil has jurisdiction to try a suit based on a promissory note. So far as this point is concerned, the respondent bases his contention on entries 28

arguments.claim: The Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay because it confers jurisdiction on the new court not only in respect of Provincial List II matters but also Federal List I matters like promissory notes (entry 28 List I), contravening entry 53 List I.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the respondents that the Act is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay, because it confers jurisdiction on the new court not only in respect of matters which the Provincial Legislature is competent to legislate upon under List II of the 7th Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, but also in regard to matters in respect of which only the Central or Federal Legislature can legislate under List I  such as, for instance, promissory notes, which is one of the subjects mentioned in entry 28 of List I . To understand this argument, it is necessary to refer to entry 53 of List I, entries 1 and 2 of List II and also entry 15 of List III.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is necessary to refer to entry 53 of List I, entries 1 and 2 of List II and also entry 15 of List III. These entries run as follows - Entry 53, List I

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 1 List II 'administration of justice, constitution and organization of all courts' includes general jurisdiction over all civil matters; entries 53 List I and 2 List II confer special/additional jurisdiction only.

arguments.claim: Entry 1 List II 'administration of justice, constitution and organization of all courts' has wide meaning including power and jurisdiction of courts to administer justice over all civil suits irrespective of subject-matter.

anchor.surface_text: A reference to three Legislative Lists shows that a administration of justice is entirely a provincial subject on which only the Provincial Legislature can legislate. The same remark applies to constitution and organization of all courts except the Federal Court. The expression administration of justice has a wide meaning, and includes administration of civil as well as criminal justice, and in my opinion entry 1 in List II, which I have quoted, is a complete and self contained entry.

arguments.claim: Entries 53 List I, 2 List II confer special powers to legislate on courts' jurisdiction re specific list matters, as concomitant to substantive legislation, not limiting general jurisdiction under entry 1 List II.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises as to the exact meaning of entry 2 of List II and entry 53 of List I, which are said to militate against the above construction. These entries, in my opinion, confer special powers on Provincial and Central Legislatures, as opposed to the general power conferred on the Provincial Legislature by entry 1 of List II, the special powers being the logical consequence or concomitant of the power of the two Legislatures to legislate with regard to the matters included in their respective Legislative Lists.

arguments.claim: Section 9 CPC supports general jurisdiction of courts unless expressly barred, consistent with provincial power under List II entry 1.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, reference may be made to Section 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, which provides that - the Courts shall have jurisdiction to try all suits of a civil nature excepting suits of which their cognizance is either expressly or impliedly barred.

arguments.claim: Legislative practice pre and post 1935 GOI Act shows provinces constitute courts with general jurisdiction, special jurisdiction added as needed.

anchor.surface_text: A reference to the Acts passed after the enactment of the Government of India Act, 1935, will show that special provisions with regard to the jurisdiction of courts have been made even after the passing of that Act, in a large number of Central and local Acts. Confining ourselves to the Acts passed by the Bombay Legislature...

arguments.claim: Respondent's interpretation leads to absurd results, e.g., courts without jurisdiction over List I matters until federal legislation.

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation which is sought to be put on the entries by the respondent is in my opinion open to the following objections - It involves the curtailment of the meaning of the expression administration of justice in such a way as to rob it of its primary content - the jurisdiction and powers of the court, without which justice cannot be administered.

arguments.claim: City Civil Court has jurisdiction over suit on promissory note as general jurisdiction under Act, not requiring federal conferment under entry 53 List I.

anchor.surface_text: Perhaps, it will be simpler to deal at this stage with the third question, namely, whether the Bombay City Civil has jurisdiction to try a suit based on a promissory note. So far as this point is concerned, the respondent bases his contention on entries 28 and 33 of List I.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 9 of the Civil Procedure Code, and the criminal companyrts used to try all criminal cases which are triable under the Code of Criminal Procedure. The

arguments.court_reasoning: Covered by answer to first question; supported by Prafulla Kumar case pith and substance.

arguments.claim: Section 4 Act delegates legislative power to Provincial Government by allowing it to decide jurisdiction up to Rs25k, invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The second point raised on behalf of the respondent relates to the validity of Section 4 of the Act, which runs as follows - Subject to the exceptions specified in Section 3, the Provincial Government, may by notification in the Official Gazette, invest the City Civil Court with jurisdiction to receive, try and dispose of all suits...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: with the same power. Perhaps, it will be simpler to deal at this stage with the third question, namely, whether the Bombay City Civil has jurisdictio

arguments.court_reasoning: Conditional legislation; legislature fixed policy and limits, executive applies when.

arguments.claim: Section 4 is conditional legislation per Queen v Burah, legislature fixed max limit Rs25k, govt decides timing.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned provision is an instance of what the Privy Council has designated as conditional legislation, and does not really delegate any legislative power but merely prescribes as to how effect is to be given to what the Legislature has already decided.

arguments.claim: Entries 1 and 2 List II must be read together; entry 1 excludes jurisdiction, entry 2 limits to List II matters only.

anchor.surface_text: On the first point, learned counsel for the first respondent urged that Section 100 of the Government of India Act, 1935, read with entries 53 of List I, 2 of List II and 15 of List III... conferred power on Legislatures in British India to make laws with respect to jurisdiction of courts only in relation to matters falling within their respective legislative fields

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nistered. It makes it necessary to read entry 2 of List II as part of entry 1 of the same List, though it has been separately numbered as an independe

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 1 gives general power; entry 2 for special jurisdiction re List II; pith and substance for overlaps.

arguments.claim: Act in pith and substance under List II entry 2 read with entry 1, conferring general jurisdiction; incidental encroachment on List I entry 53 allowed.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned Act must, in its pith and substance, be attributed to List II, as the legislators of Bombay were certainly not conferring on the new court, which they were constituting under the Act, jurisdiction with respect to any of the matters in List I.

arguments.claim: Pre-1935 legislative practice supports provincial courts having general jurisdiction over all matters unless specially barred.

anchor.surface_text: This view is strongly reinforced by a consideration of the legislative practice prevailing in this country prior to the passing of the Government of India Act, 1935. That it is legitimate to have regard to legislative practice in determining the scope of legislative powers has been recognised in decisions of high authority

arguments.claim: Section 4 delegates legislative power, invalid per Jitendranath Gupta; legislature did not fix policy on higher jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question the High Court held that Section 4 of the Act was inoperative as it purported to delegate the law-making powers of the legislature to an outside authority and hence the notification issued in pursuance of it had no effect whatsoever

court_response_anchor.surface_text: companyld be numberquestion of companyflict between two entries in the same list and that the natural meaning of one should number be restricted simpl

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature fixed initial Rs10k and max Rs25k policy; govt executes conditionally; distinguishes Jitendra.

arguments.claim: Sections 3 and 4 together show legislature fixed policy: initial Rs10k, max Rs25k; Section 4 conditional execution, not delegation.

anchor.surface_text: The policy of the legislature in regard to the pecuniary jurisdiction of the court that was being set up was settled by Sections 3 and 4 of the Act and it was to the effect that initially its pecuniary jurisdiction will be limited to Rs. 10,000 and that in future if circumstances make it desirable - and this was left to the determination of the Provincial Government - it could be given jurisdiction to hear cases up to the value of Rs. 25,000.

arguments.claim: Section 4 analogous to Queen v Burah conditional legislation on territorial extension; valid.

anchor.surface_text: In Queen v. Burah 5 I.A. 178, Section 9 of Act XXII of 1869, which was a piece of legislation analogous to Section 4 of the City Civil Court Act, was held intra vires by their Lordships of the Privy Council.

arguments.claim: Act valid under entry 1 List II as administration of justice includes conferring ordinary civil jurisdiction on constituted court.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, the Act deals with administration of justice and constitutes a court for that purpose and confers ordinary civil jurisdiction upon it, in my opinion, the legislation clearly falls within the legislative competence of the Provincial Legislature and is covered by item 1 of List II of Schedule 7.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gh Court for filing a summary suit against the second respondent to recover a sum of Rs. 11,704-2-4 alleged to be due under promissory numbere. This s

arguments.claim: Each entry in lists independent; entry 2 List II supplements entry 1, does not limit general jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Each item in List II is an independent item, supplementary of each other, and not limited by each other in any way. Item 1 having given the general power to the Provincial Legislature with regard to all matters of administration of justice...

arguments.claim: With Governor-General assent, Act valid under List II entry 1 and List III entry 4 (civil procedure including jurisdiction).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad, the learned Attorney-General, who appeared on behalf of the appellant, in supporting the impugned Act, argued before us that for the purpose of deciding this appeal, we might also refer to entry 4 of List III. His contention was that the impugned Act having had the assent

arguments.court_reasoning: Useful but not necessary; entry 1 List II sufficient.

arguments.claim: Jitendranath Gupta distinguishes: there govt could modify/re-enact; here no, just timing of fixed policy.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the decision in the Bihar case has no application to the case in hand. The Federal Court there was dealing with an Act which contained the following provisions in Section 1, sub-section (3) - The Act shall remain in force for a period of one year...

arguments.claim: High Court erred in saying legislature never applied mind to >Rs10k jurisdiction; fixed max Rs25k explicitly.

anchor.surface_text: I find it difficult to accept this view. Without applying its mind to the question as to whether the new Court which it was setting up should have a jurisdiction higher than Rs. 10,000, how could the legislature possibly enact in Section 4 that the pecuniary jurisdiction of the new court would not exceed Rs. 25,000.
